folder: Greenwich Street & Canal Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
475 Greenwich Street, adjoining the S.E. corner of Canal Street. Building concerned is a 2-story frame house with a brick front.

About 1912.

Gift of Samuel Landsman.

folder: Canal Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Canal Street, at and adjoining the North West corner of Greenwich Street. The four small buildings that used to occupy the corner have been demolished. The little frame stable is #527 Canal Street. September 27th, 1927

(2) The same, after demolition of "L". May 5th, 1941

Photographs by, P.L. Sperr,

folder: Canal Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Canal Street, at and adjoining the North West corner of Greenwich Street. The four small buildings that used to occupy the corner have been demolished. The little frame stable is #527 Canal Street. September 27th, 1927

(2) The same, after demolition of "L". May 5th, 1941

Photographs by, P.L. Sperr,

folder: Canal Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Canal Street, south side, east from Greenwich (9th Avenue "El" thereon), to Watts (left) Streets, showing a triangular block bounded by these thoroughfares. A former 4 story structure (No. 500 Canal and 477 Greenwich Streets) has been replaced by a gasoline station and opened to view the side of a frame house No. 475 Greenwich Street. Adjacent to same is a similar 2 1/2 story frame building with brick front, bearing No. 473. Across these buildings appears lofts on the south side of Watts Street; the narrower of which is to be rebuilt and have a modern translucent glass front. For an account of same see the New York Times of October 20, 1937, page 42 L.

View No. 2 shows details of the structures occupying the middle of this block front. The narrow 2 story affair at the left is a rear entrance to an addition to the aforementioned No 473 Greenwich Street. The adjoining property (No's. 496 and 498 Canal Street) is composed of 2 units; one, two stories in height and the other, one story. Note the doorway leading into the back yard of the first 2 1/2 story frame dwelling. In this instance the photographer is viewing towards Greenwich Street and upon which appear lofts on the west side of same.

View No. 3 is similar to No. 1. Note at the left the absence of the 4 story brick structure and the gas station replacing same, thereby giving this front an additional vacancy. The 12 story factory at that margin replaced the 3 story pitched roof residences that appear to the left in View No. 1.

P.L. Sperr

J. Clarence Davies Collection
Museum of the City of New York

October 25, 1927.
View 2: June 30, 1931
View 3: 1932.

folder: Canal Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
506, 508, 510-516 Canal Street, south side, between Greenwich and Washington Streets.
March 8, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Canal Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Canal Street, western end, from West to Greenwich Streets, looking across what used to be the little park between the north fork of Canal Street and the south fork (formerly Hoboken Street). This little park is now being cleared off and made into a triangular safety zone.

August 29, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Canal Street & Greenwich Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
N.W. corner of Canal & Greenwich St.
Jan. 6, 1941
P.L. Sperr, photographer

1-Canal 'street, west side, showing Highway Bridge.

2-Canal Street, north side and east of Greenwich Street, showing Borden's Milk Company, 15 story building at the intersection of the street.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: January 6, 1941
View 2: May 5, 1941

1-Canal 'street, west side, showing Highway Bridge.

2-Canal Street, north side and east of Greenwich Street, showing Borden's Milk Company, 15 story building at the intersection of the street.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: January 6, 1941
View 2: May 5, 1941
